title: Canarian Coalition
text:
The Canarian Coalition (, CC) is a <a href="Regionalism%20%28politics%29">regionalist</a>, <a href="Canarian%20nationalism">Canarian nationalist</a> <a href="list%20of%20political%20parties%20in%20Spain">political party in Spain</a> operating in the <a href="Canary%20Islands">Canary Islands</a>. The party's aim is for greater <a href="Autonomism%20%28political%20doctrine%29">autonomy</a> for the islands but not independence. It has been labeled as both <a href="Conservatism">conservative</a> and <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a>. The party governed the Canary Islands from 1993 to 2019.
It usually negotiates with the plurality party at the Cortes to form a majority in exchange for resources for the islands. It also governs the local administrations of <a href="Tenerife">Tenerife</a>, <a href="La%20Palma">La Palma</a>, and <a href="Fuerteventura">Fuerteventura</a>, as well as having majority control in some of the town councils on the Canary Islands.
History.
The coalition was formed in February 1993 from a grouping of five parties (the largest being the <a href="Canarian%20Independent%20Groups">Canarian Independent Groups</a>) under one banner and has governed the Canary Islands since 1993, when it replaced the former <a href="Spanish%20Socialist%20Workers%27%20Party">Spanish Socialist Workers' Party</a> (PSOE) administration after a <a href="motion%20of%20no%20confidence">motion of no confidence</a>. After entering government, CC obtained power for the regional government to levy its own taxes and a law compensating the islands for their distance from the mainland. The coalition became a single party in 2005.
The political parties that formed the Coalition were:
